title: Conduct an AMOC (at most one changepoint) hypothesis test — amoc_test
text: data matrix dataframe, row observation column dimension. ranks Optional data already ranked. depth Depth function choice.

title: Conduct an AMOC (at most one changepoint) hypothesis test — amoc_test
text: estimated changepoint p-value.

title: Conduct an AMOC (at most one changepoint) hypothesis test — amoc_test
text: depth arguments follows: FM: Frainman-Muniz depth RPD: Random projection depth LTR: \(L^2\) norm depth, suitable detecting changes norm FMd: Frainman-Muniz depth data first order derivative RPDd: Random projection depth data first order derivative

title: Conduct an AMOC (at most one changepoint) hypothesis test — amoc_test
code: test_data <- rbind(replicate(3,rnorm(200,1,1)), #before changepoint                    replicate(3,rnorm(200,1,5))) #after changepoint  amoc_test(test_data) #> $changepoint #> [1] 200 #>  #> $p.value #> [1] 0 #>  #> $method #> [1] "AMOC test (KWCChangepoint)" #>

what: Find changepoints using data-driven depth-based wild binary segmentation — dwbs
title: Find changepoints using data-driven depth-based wild binary segmentation — dwbs
text: Find changepoints using data-driven depth-based wild binary segmentation

title: Find changepoints using data-driven depth-based wild binary segmentation — dwbs
code: dwbs(   data,   numInt = 10,   thresh = 1.3584,   alpha = 1,   depth = c("hs", "spat", "mahal", "mahal75") )

title: Find changepoints using data-driven depth-based wild binary segmentation — dwbs
text: data matrix dataframe, row observation column dimension. numInt Number subintervals generated. thresh Numeric scalar; detection threshold. Larger values make detection conservative. alpha Set 1 default, applying standard SIC penalty. Set number larger 1 strengthened SIC. depth Depth function choice, 'hs' halfspace depth default. Users can also choose 'mahal' Mahalanobis, 'mahal75' Mahalanobis MCD, 'spat' spatial depth.

title: Find changepoints using data-driven depth-based wild binary segmentation — dwbs
text: list changepoints.

title: Find changepoints using data-driven depth-based wild binary segmentation — dwbs
text: Killick, R., P. Fearnhead, . . Eckley. “Optimal Detection Changepoints Linear Computational Cost.” Journal American Statistical Association 107, . 500 (2012): 1590–98. https://doi.org/10.1080/01621459.2012.737745. Ramsay, K., & Chenouri, S. (2023). Robust nonparametric multiple changepoint detection multivariate variability. Econometrics Statistics. https://doi.org/10.1016/j.ecosta.2023.09.001

title: Find changepoints using data-driven depth-based wild binary segmentation — dwbs
code: exdata <- rbind(replicate(3,rnorm(200)),                 replicate(3,rnorm(200,10)),                 replicate(3,rnorm(200,0.2))) dwbs(data = exdata) #> NULL  # Increasing `numInt` will result in more accurate detection dwbs(data = exdata, numInt = 100) #> [1] 180 403

title: Find changepoints using functional Kruskall-Wallis tests for covariance algorithm — fkwc
text: data Functional data fdata form, row observation column dimension. depth Depth function choice. k Penalty constant passed pruned exact linear time algorithm.

title: Find changepoints using functional Kruskall-Wallis tests for covariance algorithm — fkwc
text: list changepoints.

title: Find changepoints using functional Kruskall-Wallis tests for covariance algorithm — fkwc
text: depth arguments follows: FM: Frainman-Muniz depth RPD: Random projection depth LTR: \(L^2\) norm depth, suitable detecting changes norm FMd: Frainman-Muniz depth data first order derivative RPDd: Random projection depth data first order derivative penalty form $$3.74 + k\sqrt{n}$$ \(n\) number observations. case potentially correlated observations, parameter set \(k=1\). information found reference.

title: Find changepoints using functional Kruskall-Wallis tests for covariance algorithm — fkwc
text: Killick, R., P. Fearnhead, . . Eckley. “Optimal Detection Changepoints Linear Computational Cost.” Journal American Statistical Association 107, . 500 (2012): 1590–98. https://doi.org/10.1080/01621459.2012.737745. Ramsay, K., & Chenouri, S. (2025). Robust changepoint detection variability multivariate functional data. Journal Nonparametric Statistics. https://doi.org/10.1080/10485252.2025.2503891

title: Find changepoints using functional Kruskall-Wallis tests for covariance algorithm — fkwc
code: set.seed(2) # Generating 80 observations, with a changepoint (in our case a change in # kernel) at observation 40 n  <- 80 k0 <- 40 T  <- 30 t  <- seq(0, 1, length.out = T)   # Both kernels K1 and K2 are Gaussian (or squared exponential) kernels but # with different lengthscale values K_se <- function(s, t, ell) exp(- ( (s - t)^2 ) / (2 * ell^2)) K1   <- outer(t, t, function(a,b) K_se(a,b, ell = 0.20)) K2   <- outer(t, t, function(a,b) K_se(a,b, ell = 0.07))  L1 <- chol(K1 + 1e-8 * diag(T)) L2 <- chol(K2 + 1e-8 * diag(T))  Z1 <- matrix(rnorm(k0 * T),      k0,      T) Z2 <- matrix(rnorm((n-k0) * T),  n - k0,  T)  # We finally have an 80 x 30 matrix where the rows are the observations and # the columns are the grid points. X  <- rbind(Z1 %*% t(L1), Z2 %*% t(L2))  fkwc(X) #> [1] 18 40

title: Multisample hypothesis test for differences in covariance operators using Functional Kruskal–Wallis Tests for Covariance — fkwc_multisample
text: Ramsay, K., & Chenouri, S. (2024). Robust nonparametric hypothesis tests differences covariance structure functional data. Canadian Journal Statistics, 52 (1), 43–78. https://doi.org/10.1002/cjs.11767

title: Multisample hypothesis test for differences in covariance operators using Functional Kruskal–Wallis Tests for Covariance — fkwc_multisample
code: set.seed(111) t <- seq(0, 1, length.out = 200)  ### Generating three sets of brownian curves with different kernels # Brownian process 1 fd1 <- fda.usc::rproc2fdata(n = 20, t = t, sigma = "brownian",                            par.list = list(scale = 10, theta = 1)) fd1_d <- fda.usc::fdata.deriv(fd1)  # Brownian process 2 fd2 <- fda.usc::rproc2fdata(n = 20, t = t, sigma = "brownian",                            par.list = list(scale = 1, theta = 1)) fd2_d <- fda.usc::fdata.deriv(fd2)  # Brownian process 3 fd3 <- fda.usc::rproc2fdata(n = 20, t = t, sigma = "brownian",                            par.list = list(scale = 1, theta = 5)) fd3_d <- fda.usc::fdata.deriv(fd3)  # Functional data in one matrix and first order derivatives in another matrix funcdata <- rbind(fd1$data, fd2$data, fd3$data) funcderivs <- rbind(fd1_d$data, fd2_d$data, fd3_d$data)  fkwc_multisample(data = funcdata,                  derivs = funcderivs,                  g = factor(rep(1:3, each = 20)),                  p = 1000) #> $statistic #> [1] 38.56262 #>  #> $p.value #> [1] 4.228953e-09 #>

title: Pairwise comparison post-hoc hypothesis test for differences in covariance operators using Functional Kruskal–Wallis Tests for Covariance. — fkwc_posthoc
code: set.seed(111) t <- seq(0, 1, length.out = 200)  ### Generating three sets of brownian curves with different kernels # Brownian process 1 fd1 <- fda.usc::rproc2fdata(n = 20, t = t, sigma = "brownian",                            par.list = list(scale = 10, theta = 1)) fd1_d <- fda.usc::fdata.deriv(fd1)  # Brownian process 2 fd2 <- fda.usc::rproc2fdata(n = 20, t = t, sigma = "brownian",                            par.list = list(scale = 1, theta = 1)) fd2_d <- fda.usc::fdata.deriv(fd2)  # Brownian process 3 fd3 <- fda.usc::rproc2fdata(n = 20, t = t, sigma = "brownian",                            par.list = list(scale = 1, theta = 5)) fd3_d <- fda.usc::fdata.deriv(fd3)  # Functional data in one matrix and first order derivatives in another matrix funcdata <- rbind(fd1$data, fd2$data, fd3$data) funcderivs <- rbind(fd1_d$data, fd2_d$data, fd3_d$data)  fkwc_posthoc(data = funcdata,              derivs = funcderivs,              g = factor(rep(1:3, each = 20)),              p = 1000) #>              1            2            3 #> 1           NA 3.439663e-07 2.198030e-07 #> 2 3.439663e-07           NA 9.999899e-01 #> 3 2.198030e-07 9.999899e-01           NA

what: KWCChangepoint: Robust Changepoint Detection for Functional and Multivariate Data — KWCChangepoint-package
title: KWCChangepoint: Robust Changepoint Detection for Functional and Multivariate Data — KWCChangepoint-package
text: group functions detect test changes covariance structures functional data, well changepoint detection multivariate data generally. Method detecting non-stationarity resting state fMRI scans seen Ramsay, K., & Chenouri, S. (2025) doi:10.1080/10485252.2025.2503891  implemented 'fmri_changepoints()'. Also includes depth- rank-based implementation WBS algorithm detecting multiple changepoints multivariate data.

text: data four dimensional array, fourth dimension time stamp. p Number random vector projections, set 100 default. k Penalty constant passed pruned exact linear time algorithm.

title: Detect changepoints in a resting state fMRI scan — fmri_changepoints
text: list changepoints.

title: Detect changepoints in a resting state fMRI scan — fmri_changepoints
text: penalty form $$3.74 + k\sqrt{n}$$ \(n\) number observations. case potentially correlated observations, parameter set \(k=1\). information found reference. example document simple "toy example", good fMRI data simulation requires dependencies. generating fMRI data, see neuRosim::simVOLfmri(), neuRosim::simTSrestingstate().

title: Detect changepoints in a resting state fMRI scan — fmri_changepoints
text: Ramsay, K., & Chenouri, S. (2025). Robust changepoint detection variability multivariate functional data. Journal Nonparametric Statistics. https://doi.org/10.1080/10485252.2025.2503891

title: Detect changepoints in a resting state fMRI scan — fmri_changepoints
code: # In order to replicate how a changepoint would appear in a resting-state # fMRI scan in a manner that is not computationally expensive, this example # constructs an image of a 3D ball taken at 12 time stamps. The noise, and # therefore the covariance function, changes at time stamp 6. x_dim <- 24 y_dim <- 24 z_dim <- 10 time_dim <- 12 image_array <- array(0, dim = c(x_dim, y_dim, z_dim, time_dim))  center <- c(x_dim / 2, y_dim / 2, z_dim / 2) radius <- min(x_dim, y_dim, z_dim) / 4  set.seed(42)  for (t in 1:time_dim) {   for (x in 1:x_dim) {     for (y in 1:y_dim) {       for (z in 1:z_dim) {         dist_from_center <- sqrt((x - center[1])^2 + (y - center[2])^2 + (z - center[3])^2)         if (dist_from_center <= radius) {           # Adding noise with increasing variability at timestamp 6           if (t <= 6) {             noise <- rnorm(1, mean = 0, sd = 0.1)  # Low variability noise           } else {             noise <- rnorm(1, mean = 0, sd = 2)  # High variability noise           }           image_array[x, y, z, t] <- noise         } else {           # Add lower intensity noise outside the ball           image_array[x, y, z, t] <- rnorm(1, mean = 0, sd = 0.005)         }       }     }   } } fmri_changepoints(image_array, k = 0.1, p = 10) #> Warning: executing %dopar% sequentially: no parallel backend registered #> [1] 6
